key_points: Harris County, Texas faced severe impacts during February's winter storm, worse than the rest of the state.
Study by University of Houston's Hobby School of Public Affairs highlights the extensive loss of power and water in Harris County.
66 people died in Harris County alone, nearly one-third of the almost 200 storm-related deaths in Texas.
89% of Harris County residents surveyed lost electrical power, compared to 71% statewide.
Residents faced significant challenges, including loss of internet and difficulties obtaining food.
The majority supports the development of alternative energy sources like wind and solar to enhance energy security.
High percentage of residents resorted to unsafe heating methods, risking carbon monoxide poisoning.
Survey indicates that storm preparedness was inadequate, with 79% believing power cuts were not equitably distributed.
The Electric Reliability Council of Texas and Governor Greg Abbott received high disapproval ratings for their handling of the storm.
Text alerts from local and county government were crucial for residents during the storm, despite cell reception issues.
spokespersons: Mark P. Jones (Senior Research Associate, Hobby School)
